body.p: To test whether or not the mean circuit board thickness is 12 mm with the new process, for which one of the following would neither the z-test nor the t-test be justified?

multiple_choice.choice: A random sample of 9 circuit boards is tested; the only available standard deviation is the one that is computed for the sample; and the histogram of the data is as shown above in histogram A.
A random sample of 40 circuit boards is tested; the only available standard deviation is the one that is computed for the sample; and the histogram of the data is as shown above in histogram B.
A random sample of 35 circuit boards is tested; the population standard deviation sigma is known; and the histogram of the data is as shown above in histogram C.
A random sample of 9 circuit boards is tested; the only available standard deviation is the one that is computed for the sample; and the histogram of the data is as shown above in histogram D.

response.feedback: Incorrect. In this case, although the sample size is relatively small (only 9 boards) and although sigma is unknown, notice that the population can be reasonably assumed to be normal (because the data distribution is reasonably unimodal and symmetric). So in this case, a t-test would be justified.

Incorrect. In this case, although sigma is unknown, and although the population cannot be assumed to be normal in shape (since the data distribution shows severe skewness), notice that the sample size is reasonably large. So in this case, a t-test would be justified.

Incorrect. In this case, although the population cannot be assumed to be normal in shape (since the data distribution shows severe skewness), notice that sigma is known, and notice that the sample size is greater than 30. So in this case, by the Central Limit Theorem, a z-test would be justified.

Correct. In this case, the sample size is relatively small (only 9 boards), sigma is unknown, and the population cannot be reasonably assumed to vary normally (because the data distribution is noticeably skewed). So in this case, nether the z-test nor the t-test would be justified to conduct formal statistical inference. (A different sort of test called a "non-parametric" test might be justified, but that is beyond the scope of this course.)
